The numerical results reveal that the exploited fiber-optic model with low dispersion (see [20], p. 154), [10], [17], [21], [22] is not sufficiently accurate for increased symbol rates in a DM fiber-optical link due to the high group velocity dispersion.
We neglect the effect of chromatic dispersion in this paper, which makes this analysis applicable to fiber-optic systems with low dispersion, similarly as, e.g., [10], [17], [21], [22].
Moreover, we consider the noise within the optical signal bandwidth, i.e., ignoring the Kerr effect induced from out-of-band signal and noise in a same way as [10].

If a 4-D signal \${\bf S} = (S_{x},S_{y})\$, consisting of 2-D components from a signal set \${\cal M}\$, is transmitted on the two orthogonal polarizations, x and y, of a fiber channel, it is readily seen that each fiber span according to (2) contributes the overall NLPN [10] \$\varphi = \gamma P_{k} L_{\rm eff}\$ to the transmitted signal, where is the effective nonlinear length of each span and \$P_{k} = \vert S_{x} + \sum_{i=1}^{k}n_{x}^i\vert^{2}+\vert S_{y} + \sum_{i=1}^{k}n_{y}^i\vert^{2}\$ is the input power of the \$k\$th fiber span.

context.text: Recently, we have proposed [9] a hybrid CPU-GPU multilevel preconditioner with a moderate memory footprint for solving a sparse system of equations resulting from finite element method (FEM) using higher-order elements.

In this letter, we propose several improvements to the solver [9] that allow one not only to achieve a much faster execution in both single and double precision, but also to accommodate much larger real and complex-valued problems within fast GPU memory.

In order to be able to discuss the tuning of the preconditioner for solving a sparse system of equations resulting from FEM using higher-order elements and identify throughput and memory bottlenecks, it is necessary to recall basic components of the implementation [9] and point out its limitations.

The computational kernel of the hybrid solver proposed in [9] relies on a sparse matrix-vector product that, for high throughput, was implemented using the ELLPACK-R sparse matrix storage scheme [11].
The second drawback of the preconditioner presented in [9] is the time spent on a direct solve at the lowest level.
For instance, the solution time for the problem considered in [9] and for six cores is only 2% shorter than for one core (32.75 and 32.23 ms, respectively).
Note that this setup is different from the one that we used in [9] (GeForce 285 GTX—240 cores and Intel i7—4 cores, 2.66 GHz).

context.text: Spectral unmixing concerns the decomposition of a pixel spectrum into its constituent spectra, with the motivation being that the surface area of a single pixel contains a low number of “pure” materials, each with a given fraction [1].

Most spectral unmixing algorithms start from the linear mixing assumption [1], or the assumption that an observed spectrum is a linear combination of a limited number of endmember spectra, where the linear coefficient of each endmember is its abundance.
